newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Unisource partners to merge international networks.
newsitem.headline: Unisource partners to merge international networks.

text.p: Unisource, the Euroepean telecoms joint venture between Dutch PTT, Telia of Sweden and Swiss Telecom PTT said on Wednesday its partners had agreed to merge their international networks.
"The shareholders, (Dutch PTT unit) PTT Telecom, Telia and Swiss Telecom have agreed in principle to the merger of their respective international networks," a Unisource spokeswoman told Reuters.
"It is to create economies of scale and to be more competitive in the European market. Our other partners, such as AT&T Corp, can also benefit," she added.
A statement from Unisource said the international carrier units would be merged into Unisource Carrier Services (UCS) as of January 1, 1998.
It said the merger would create Europe's leading international carrier with initial revenues of $2.0 billion and around 900 employees based around Europe.
UCS will be part of Unisource and have its headquarters in Wallisellen/Zurich in Switzerland, the statement said.

"We are creating a multi-billion (dollar) company which further expands our presence in Europe and puts us in a leading position in the global telecommunications wholesale market," Unisource president Paul Smits said in the statement.

Unisource said the deal created Europe's most extensive centrally managed pan-European carrier. "It is foreseen that the pan-European network could eventually be linked to AT&T's network...creating a truly global network," it said.
Unisource owns 60 percent and AT&T 40 percent of their business telecoms venture, AT&T-Unisource.

In April the Unisource partners asked fourth member Telefonica of Spain to leave the group after news it had forged an incompatible link with Concert, a rival business telecoms alliance between British Telecommunications Plc and MCI Communications Corp.
Unisource has timed completion of the merger to coincide with the European Union's date for liberalisation of European telecommunications services.
"By further strengthening our carrier business we are ideally positioned to take maximum advantage of the opportunities the liberalised...market will present," it said.
